Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
Project Number: 54367-002 
Transaction Technical Assistance (TRTA) 
December 2020 
 
 
India: Strengthening Micro, Small, and Medium 
Enterprises Ecosystem Development 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Distribution of this document is restricted until it has been approved by the Board of Directors. 
Following such approval, ADB will disclose the document in accordance with ADB’s Access to 
Information Policy.

I.  THE ENSUING PROGRAM 
 
1.  India has about 63.4 million micro, small, and medium enterprises (MSMEs). Together 
they account for about 30% to the country’s gross domestic product (GDP) and 50% of exports, 
and employ 111 million persons.1 The government’s target for 2024 is for MSMEs to account for 
50% of GDP and 75% of exports, while employing 150 million people, in line with a target to make 
India a $5 trillion economy.2 The coronavirus disease (COVID-19) has severely impacted the lives 
of informal microenterprises, constituting 99% of the MSMEs, owing to lack of managerial 
resources, capacities, and backward-forward linkages to cope with economic downturn. The 
government’s long-term vision to achieve economic growth, creating jobs, and reducing poverty 
in India through MSME development requires critical interventions in the MSME policy and 
institutional frameworks. While the government’s Self-Reliant India Mission (Atmanibhar Bharat 
Abhiyaan), announced in May 2020, is conceived to provide liquidity and institutional support for 
MSME survival in the midst of COVID-19,3 an extra effort is needed to channel limited public 
resources  in  a  more  effective  manner  to  improve  MSME  business  practices,  facilitate 
transformation of their business models, and encourage MSMEs to seize market opportunities 
under the post-COVID-19 “new normal.”  
 
2.  The  ensuing  results-based  lending  (RBL)  program—Strengthening  MSME  Cluster 
Ecosystem  through  Institutional  Network  of  Enterprise  Development  Centers—will  improve 
service delivery to MSMEs building on the four ongoing schemes of the Ministry of Micro, Small, 
and Medium Enterprises (MOMSME)4 adding significant value in MSME cluster planning and 
implementation, in line with the government’s Self-Reliant India Mission. The RBL program is 
aligned with the following impact: economic output and employment generation by MSMEs 
increased. The program’s outcome will be improved productivity and enhanced competitiveness 
of selected MSME clusters. 5 The key outputs are (i) a network of enterprise development centers 
(EDCs) and a national resource center for enterprises (NRCE) established, (ii) MSMEs’ access 
to enterprise development services enhanced, and (iii) integrated cluster development promoted. 
 
3.  The RBL program reflects the priorities of ADB’s Country Partnership Strategy for India, 
2018–2022, which identifies boosting economic competitiveness to create better employment 
opportunities as one of the three strategic pillars.6 The RBL program supports Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) Strategy 2030 operational priority 1 (addressing remaining poverty and reducing 
inequalities); operational priority 2 (accelerating progress in gender equality); and operational 
priority 6 (strengthening governance and institutional capacity).7 The RBL program is estimated 
to cost $500 million, of which $250 million will be financed by a regular loan from ADB’s ordinary 
 
1  Government of India, Ministry of Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises (MOMSME). 2019. Annual Report 2018–19. 
Delhi; and Business Standard. 2019. MSMEs Contribute 29.7% Of India's GDP. 2 December 2019. 
2  Government of India, MOMSME, Press Information Bureau. 2019. Shri Nitin Gadkari expresses commitment to raise 
MSME's contribution to GDP to 50 percent. Delhi.  
3  Government of India. 2020. Atmanirbhar Bharat Part 1: Businesses including MSMEs. May 2020. 
4  The four ongoing schemes are: (i) Credit Linked Capital Subsidy for Technology Upgradation, (ii) Micro and Small 
Enterprises—Cluster  Development  Program,  (iii)  Entrepreneurship  and  Skill  Development  Program,  and  (iv) 
Schemes of Fund for Regeneration of Traditional Industries. The boundary of the ensuing RBL program is subject to 
change during its processing. 
5  An MSME cluster refers to a geographic concentration of enterprises, mostly with similar or complementary products 
and services, who derive advantages from their agglomeration, proximity, and aligned interests. Strategic cluster 
development refers to a planned approach for development of MSME clusters for maximization of their growth and 
business potential. 
6  ADB. 2017. Country Partnership Strategy: India, 2018-2022 - Accelerating Inclusive Economic Transformation. 
Manila 
7  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. Manila.

2 
capital resources. The ensuing program and the  transaction technical assistance (TA) are 
included in the Country Operations Business Plan for India, 2021–2023.8  
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
4.  There are multiple government schemes for MSMEs under the MOMSME and other 
ministries overseeing food processing, textiles, and other industries.9 However, these schemes 
are  supply-driven,  segmented,  and  suffer  from  limited  resources  and  outreach.  Limited 
coordination among different ministries at the policy level, lack of integration at the project 
planning and implementation level, and insufficient monitoring and evaluation for each scheme 
further reduce the effectiveness of individual schemes. These inefficiencies should be urgently 
addressed to promote MSME development while driving economic recovery post-COVID-19. It is 
critical  for  the  government  to  support  the  transformation  of  survival-oriented  informal 
microbusinesses to growth-oriented formal SMEs by (i) providing relevant support to individual 
MSMEs in entrepreneurship development, access to financial resources, technology and human 
resources, and business management skill development; (ii) integrating MSMEs into dynamic 
clusters that are part of global value chains (GVCs);10 and (iii) establishing effective institutional 
mechanisms to deliver the intended results.  
 
5.  Against  this  backdrop,  the  ensuing  program  aims  to  sequentially  enhance  the 
effectiveness of the four MSME schemes (footnote 4) through the following two thematic pillars. 
 
6.  Thematic  Pillar  A:  Institutional  strengthening  through  enterprise  development 
center network. District industries centers, under the administrative control of state governments, 
provide capacity development support for MSMEs. Given that district industries centers face 
capacity constraints to undertake these functions,11 the MOMSME in 2018 conceptualized setting 
up EDCs at the district level to provide business advisory support and nurture entrepreneurship 
development. While the ministry has launched 94 EDCs, they require enhancement to provide 
specialized  technical  advice  to  strengthen  MSMEs’  international  competitiveness,  navigate 
regulatory processes, incubate new local enterprises, and bridge information gaps. The ensuing 
program will support the MOMSME to develop business models for the private sector, industry 
associations,  and/or  civil  society  organizations  to  professionally  manage  EDCs  (para.  11). 
Furthermore, an NRCE will be set up under the MOMSME to oversee EDCs’ service delivery, 
mobilize specialized experts, and serve as a central knowledge hub and discussion forum for 
coordinating policy interventions. In addition, to improve MSMEs’ access to finance, skilled labor, 
and markets and support their survival in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic, a digital platform 
(virtual EDC) will be operationalized to complement the role of physical EDCs. 
 
 
8  ADB. 2020. Country Operations Business Plan: India, 2021–2023. Manila. The size of the ensuing RBL program is 
subject to change during its processing.  
9 The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 9 November 2020. 
10 Government of India, MOMSME. 2019. Annual Report 2018–19. Delhi. About 99% of MSMEs are microbusinesses 
and 83% are unregistered. GVCs refer to international production sharing, a phenomenon whereby production is 
broken into activities and tasks carried out in different countries. United Nations Industrial Development Organization. 
2019. What are global value chains and why do they matter? August 2019.  
11 In most cases, district industries centers lack adequate technical manpower, expertise, finance, and results-
orientation; and offer basic administrative services such as assisting MSMEs in applying for government financial 
assistance.

3 
7.  Thematic Pillar B: Strategic cluster development efforts. Cluster-level solutions can 
(i) improve access to common infrastructure facilities to reduce costs; (ii) increase proximity to 
related industries for sourcing, learning, networking, and technological upgrading; (iii) improve 
access to training programs for quality assurance and branding; and (iv) leverage collective 
bargaining power for negotiating with government agencies to remove regulatory barriers. Central 
and state governments have been providing financial support to MSMEs for setting up common 
facilities centers (CFCs) under their respective cluster development programs.12 However, these 
CFCs are generally developed on a standalone basis without strategic cluster development 
planning, which can render their usefulness suboptimal. The ensuing RBL program will support 
integration and alignment of various cluster initiatives.13 A strategic approach towards integrated 
cluster development will also strengthen post-COVID-19 recovery and resilience to the affected 
MSMEs  and  their  employees.  The  RBL  program  will  focus  on  selected  priority  industries 
announced under the Self-Reliant India Mission and in selected areas.14 
 
8.  The transaction TA is primarily aimed at advising on the innovative approaches in planning 
and execution of these two thematic pillars of the RBL program, including support for establishing 
professional management of the proposed institutional setup, supporting the development of 
associated government operational systems, and building capacity at selected state and cluster 
levels for new initiatives such as strategic cluster development to achieve demonstrative effects.  
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
9.  The impact of the TA, aligned with the impact of the ensuing RBL program, is economic 
output and employment generated by MSMEs increased. The TA will have the following outcome, 
also aligned with the RBL program: institutional framework strengthened for service delivery and 
MSME cluster ecosystem development. TA outputs 1 and 2 will primarily support pillar A and TA 
output 3 will support pillar B. The TA outputs will mirror those of the RBL program. 
 
10.  Output 1: Network of enterprise development centers and a national resource 
center  for  enterprises  established  and  operationalized.  This  output  will  develop  the 
institutional framework and mechanisms of the NRCE and EDCs to support improved service 
delivery to MSMEs and their clusters. Key activities are knowledge advisory to the MOMSME on 
(i)  developing  a  sound  governance  system  for  the  NRCE  and  operationalizing  its  project 
management unit; (ii) strengthening the NRCE as a knowledge hub for MSME policy and a forum 
for coordination between central ministries and state governments; (iii) advising the government 
and the NRCE in developing a one-stop-shop online service platform for MSMEs (virtual EDC 
platform); (iv) advising the government in procuring service providers for EDCs and NRCE; and 
(v) developing an operational framework for NRCE to supplement EDCs’ activities, such as 
mobilizing highly-technical experts for specialized services and promoting exports and value 
chain development in strategic sectors.  
 
 
12 A CFC refers to a facility that supports part of the production process or value chain common to the cluster MSMEs. 
Examples include testing facilities, raw material depots, tool rooms, effluent treatment plants, and training. 
13Integration  will  include  both  hard  infrastructure  (last  mile  connectivity,  utilities,  effluent  treatment)  and  soft 
interventions such as skills programs and training programs that enhance the value added by CFCs. 
14 The following 20 priority industries were identified under the Self-Reliant India Mission: (i) electronic products; (ii) 
aluminum for defense, construction, and packaging; (iii) auto parts; (iv) electric vehicle components and integrated 
circuits; (v) textiles; (vi) leather and footwear; (vii) Indian ready-to-eat segment; (viii) medical equipment; (ix) 
agrochemicals; (x) capital goods for industrial machinery and transmission lines; (xi) ethanol; (xii) television; (xiii) 
processed marine products like shrimp and tuna; (xiv) food processing; (xv) furniture; (xvi) steel; (xvii) closed circuit 
camera; (xviii) toys; (xix) sporting goods; and (xx) gym equipment.

4 
11.  Innovative solutions will be introduced under this output. First, experts will be recruited to 
advise on a new institutional framework for EDCs and the NRCE to leverage private sector know-
how  in  providing  better  service  delivery.  They  will  support  the  government  to  draw  up 
performance-based management contracts between the government and the service providers 
that will manage the EDCs. The experts will also advise the government on procuring the service 
providers. Second, the TA will support the government in the roll-out of a virtual EDC platform, 
which is expected to use innovative modern technology, such as mobile application and artificial 
intelligence-powered chat bot, to expand the EDC’s business development services to MSMEs 
in remote areas and to enable the government to undertake data analytics for its better policy 
formulation.  
 
12.  Output 2: Improving micro, small, and medium enterprises’ access to enterprise 
development services. This output will improve MSMEs’ access to critical managerial resources, 
including finance and technology resources, and support MSMEs overcome regulatory barriers 
to  enterprise  development.  Key  activities  will  develop  the  capacity  of  relevant  government 
agencies for (i) developing a communication plan to publicize the services provided by the NRCE 
and EDCs; (ii) designing new trainings through EDCs to MSMEs; (iii) improving MSMEs’ access 
to finance through their effective use of existing financial market infrastructure, such as the Trade 
Receivables Discounting System,15 and advising the government on new and innovative financial 
schemes in response to COVID-19; and (iv) improving the four MOMSME support schemes 
through the RBL (footnote 4) in terms of environmental and social safeguard management, 
gender empowerment, financial management, and monitoring and evaluation.  
 
13.  Output 3: Promoting strategic cluster development. This output will support MSMEs 
to undertake cluster development in a strategic manner in cooperation with state governments by 
(i) undertaking cluster mapping and advising the government on prioritization of clusters to be 
supported; (ii) advising on the design and the implementation of development strategies of the 
selected clusters, including identification of key hard and soft infrastructure requirements and 
exploration of cluster integration to GVCs to strengthen cluster competitiveness; (iii) advising 
MSMEs  in  preparing  their  applications  to  relevant  government  support  schemes;  and  (iv) 
developing specialized trainings for cluster implementing agencies, industry associations, and/or 
MSMEs  running  cluster  special  purpose  vehicles  to  promote  business  relationships  with 
international companies. This output will also support documentation and dissemination of best 
practices and successful pilot initiatives for wider replication across India. Furthermore, this output 
will include ADB’s policy advice to MOMSME on a new financial scheme for greenfield cluster 
development to supplement the ongoing Micro and Small Enterprises—Cluster Development 
Program (footnote 4).  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,100,000, of which $1,000,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The key expenditure 
items are listed in Appendix 1. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of 
counterpart  staff,  office  accommodation,  office  supplies,  secretarial  assistance,  domestic 
transportation, and other in-kind contributions. The government was informed that approval of the 
TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing program. 
 
 
15 The Trade Receivables Discounting System is an electronic platform for facilitating the discounting of trade 
receivables of MSMEs through multiple financiers.

5 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  ADB will administer the TA. The Public Management, Financial Sector and Trade Division 
in ADB’s South Asia Department will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants. It will also act 
as the focal point and facilitate the consultants’ inputs. The MOMSME will be the executing agency 
and implementing agency. The project management unit under the MOMSME will support the TA 
consultants and coordinate their activities with the activities under the RBL program. The TA will 
be implemented from January 2021 to January 2026, since the program period covers 5 fiscal 
years (FY2022 to FY2026), and to initiate important activities prior to program implementation. 
 
16.  Implementation arrangements are summarized in the table below. Consulting inputs of 97 
person-months are envisaged at this stage but may need topping up as additional resources 
become available during project implementation. 
 
Implementation Arrangements  
Aspects   Arrangements  
Indicative implementation period   January 2021–January 2026 
Executing agency   MOMSME  
Implementing agencies   MOMSME  
Consultants   To be selected and engaged by ADB  
Firm 1: QCBS  93 person-months (including  $825,000 
(Quality: Cost ratio  30 person-months,   
of 90:10)  international)  
 
Individual selection  4 person-months,  $72,000 
international   
Disbursement   The TA resources will be disbursed following ADB's Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2020, as amended from 
time to time).  
ADB = Asian Development Bank, MOMSME = Ministry of Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises, QCBS = quality- and 
cost-based selection, TA = technical assistance.  
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
17.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions.16 The consulting firm will be engaged using the quality- and cost-based 
selection method with a standard quality-cost ratio of 90:10. All disbursements under the TA will 
be made in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2020, as 
amended from time to time).  
 
III.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis to 
India for Strengthening Micro, Small, and Medium-Sized Enterprise Ecosystem Development and 
hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
16 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

6  Appendix 1
